title: Whisper
text: Give all clues in a whisper.
example: "It squeaks... when you squeeze it... in the bath..."

title: Robot Voice
text: Give clues in a stiff, robotic voice.
example: "It. Is. Small. Yellow. Object."

title: While Doing the Robot
text: Do the robot dance while giving clues.
example: "It's... small... yellow..." *jerky arm movements*

title: Deep Serious Voice
text: Use a low, overly serious tone.
example: "This is... a small floating device... critical to all bathtub operations."

title: High-Pitched Voice
text: Speak in a high, squeaky voice.
example: "It's tiny! And it squeaks!"

title: Angry Clues
text: Sound angry or irritated by the object the whole time.
example: "Why does this silly thing squeak so much?!"

title: Describe Everything Around It
text: Describe the things, places, or context near the object instead of describing the object itself.
example: "It sits near soap. Near bubbles. Near the faucet."

title: Describe What It's Not
text: Give clues only by saying what it isn't.
example: "It's not soap. It's not a boat. It doesn't sink."

title: Three-Word Clues
text: Each clue must be exactly three words.
example: "Small floating toy." / "Bright yellow squeaker."

title: Speak Only in Questions
text: Every clue must be phrased as a question.
example: "Does it float in your bathtub?"

title: One-Syllable Words Only
text: You may only use one-syllable words. If you're not sure whether a word is one syllable, the table votes quickly to keep it moving.
example: "Small. Round. Bath friend."

title: Only Analogies
text: Every clue is "It's like ___ but ___."
example: "It's like a bath toy but squishier."

title: Adjectives & Nouns Only
text: Give clues using only adjectives (describing words) and nouns (person, place, thing).
example: "Yellow toy. Floaty duck. Squishy bath friend."

title: Verbs & Nouns Only
text: Give clues using only verbs (action words) and nouns (person, place, thing).
example: "Squeeze toy. Hear squeak. Watch float. Bath water."

title: Only Comparisons
text: Every clue must compare it to something else.
example: "It's smaller than most bath toys, and it floats better than soap."

title: Hands Do the Talking
text: Each time you say a word, your hands must be doing some deliberate gesture.
example: "It—(gesture)—floats—(gesture)—in—(gesture)—water!"

title: Two-Piece Clues
text: Every clue must come in two parts with a brief pause.
example: "It squeaks / then it floats."

title: Laughing Clues
text: Give all clues while laughing the entire time.
example: "It—haha—floats—haha—and squeaks!"

title: Tongue Out
text: Stick your tongue out and keep it out while giving clues.
example: "Iff... a... yeh-woh... bahf... toy..."

title: Jumping Jacks
text: Give clues while doing jumping jacks.
example: "It—*jump*—is—*jump*—a—*jump*—floating toy!"

title: Macarena Clues
text: Give clues while doing the Macarena.
example: "This—(pose)—little—(pose)—floater—(pose)—squeaks—(pose)."

title: Story Time
text: Start your clues with "Once upon a time..." and tell it like a story.
example: "Once upon a time... a tiny yellow toy floated proudly in the tub."

title: Movie Announcer Voice
text: Use an over-the-top movie trailer voice. Start with: "In a world..."
example: "In a world... where one squeaky toy rules the water..."

title: Singing Clues
text: Sing all your clues. Pick any genre. It doesn't have to rhyme.
example: "This little squeaker floooats alooong..."

title: Meow After Every Word
text: After every single word, add a "meow."
example: "It—meow—floats—meow—in—meow—water—meow!"

title: Excited Kindergartener
text: Give clues like an overexcited kindergartener telling their parents about this thing.
example: "And THEN it went in the bath and it was yellow and it squeaked and it FLOATED ON THE WATER and it was SO COOL!"

title: Cutest Puppy Voice
text: Give clues like you're talking to the cutest puppy ever and it understands every word.
example: "Who's a little floaty squeaky friend that sits in the bathtub, yes you are, yes you are!"

title: Infomercial Host
text: Give clues like a late-night infomercial host who really needs this to sell.
example: "Are YOU tired of boring baths? Try this amazing tiny yellow squeaker that floats on water!"

title: Favorite Thing Ever
text: Give clues like this is your absolute favorite thing in the world.
example: "It's the best—bright yellow, it squeaks, it rides the bathwater with me every single night."

title: Totally Unsure
text: Give clues like you're very unsure, using words like maybe, probably, kinda, and sort of.
example: "It maybe kinda lives in the tub, probably floats on the water, and sort of squeaks when you squeeze it."

title: Villain Monologue
text: Give clues like a villain explaining their plan to the hero.
example: "First, I put this harmless yellow thing in your tub. Then, every squeak reminds you I was here."

title: Clueless Tour Guide
text: Give clues like you're a tour guide who has never seen this object before, but must pretend you know everything about it.
example: "And here we see a rare yellow bath relic which, as you can tell, bravely floats beside the humble soap."

title: Time Traveler from the Past
text: Give clues like you're a time traveler from the past seeing this for the first time.
example: "In my village, no one owned a tiny yellow creature that rides on water and cries when you squeeze it!"

title: Time Traveler from the Future
text: Give clues like you're a time traveler from the future who knows this will destroy (or save) everything.
example: "It begins as a harmless yellow toy that floats in the tub… but in my timeline, that squeak is the first warning."

title: Forbidden Secret
text: Give clues like it's a huge secret you're absolutely not supposed to share.
example: "If anyone finds out I keep a tiny yellow squeaker hidden by the faucet, we're both in trouble."

title: Spy Instructions
text: Give clues like you're in a spy movie, passing secret instructions in public.
example: "At 1900 hours, place the small yellow floater in the tub. If it squeaks twice, you know it's the right one."

title: Careful Mobster
text: Give clues like a mobster trying not to name the thing directly because the cops are listening.
example: "Look, I ain't sayin' nothin'. There's just this little yellow thing that hangs in the tub and makes noise, capisce?"

title: It's Like, But Not That
text: Every clue must use a simile in the format "It's like … but not that."
example: "It's like a tiny boat, but not that. It's like a squeaky horn, but not that. It's like a yellow lemon, but not that."

title: Guided Meditation
text: Give clues in a calm, soothing guided-meditation voice.
example: "Breathe in... and notice the small object floating peacefully in warm water..."

title: Nature Documentary
text: Narrate clues like a nature documentary observing a rare creature in the wild.
example: "Here we observe it in its natural habitat... drifting silently near the bubbles..."

title: 5-Star Review
text: Give clues like you’re leaving an over-the-top glowing 5-star review.
example: "Absolutely life-changing. The squeak is immaculate. Would bathe again."

title: 1-Star Review
text: Give clues like you’re leaving a brutal 1-star complaint review.
example: "Terrible. Too squeaky. Floats like it owns the place. Do not recommend."

title: Safety Warnings
text: Every clue must sound like a warning label or safety instruction.
example: "Warning: may cause loud squeaking. Keep away from toddlers and dramatic splashes."

title: Trade-Offs Only
text: Every clue must be a trade-off in this format: “Great for ___, terrible for ___.”
example: "Great for bath time, terrible for silent environments."

title: Sarcastic
text: Give every clue dripping with sarcasm, like this object personally inconvenienced you.
example: "Oh yeah, it's SO subtle. Just the loudest squeak on earth."

title: Bad Salesperson
text: Give clues like you’re trying to sell it, but you’re terrible at it.
example: "Uh... it’s... yellow? It floats. I don't know, just buy it."

title: Influencer Unboxing
text: Give clues like you're unboxing it on camera. Describe what you see and what you do as you "open" it and react to it.
example: "Okay guys, we're opening it... oh my gosh, it's tiny and YELLOW—listen to that squeak!"

title: Cartoon or Video Game Character
text: Pick any character, then give clues in their voice and attitude. Stay in character.
example: "Gee, I wonder what this yellow thing could be! It's a mystery, gang!"

title: Your Favorite Impression
text: Do your go-to impression and keep it going while you give clues.
example: "Well, well, well... what do we have here? A tiny yellow squeaker, I see!"

title: Country Lawyer
text: Give clues like a small-town lawyer in a low-budget courtroom drama.
example: "Ladies and gentlemen of the jury, I submit to you that this object is small, yellow, and makes a distinctive squeaking sound when compressed."

title: Game Show Host
text: Talk like you're announcing what the contestant could win. Big energy.
example: "What do we have for them, Johnny? It's SMALL! It's YELLOW! And it SQUEAKS when you squeeze it!"

title: Reality Show Judge
text: Give clues like you're judging a contestant's submission. Confident, dramatic, and direct.
example: "I'm sorry, but this is just not working for me. It's small, it's yellow, and honestly? It's giving me nothing."
